segments.text: Welcome back.
In this second video of chapter 3,
I want to look at this idea of a rectangle rotating

in terms of angular motion.
What do I mean by that?

There is a position vector.
It is a position in a canvas relative to maybe the origin
point.
There is a velocity vector.
The velocity vector is a vector that, when applied to position,
gives instructions for where the position should move
to in the next unit of time.
So velocity moving this dot from here to there.
And then acceleration is the change in velocity.
If the object is going to turn or slow down or speed up,
that's an acceleration.
So maybe it's turning here.
And then it gets to be we have this new velocity vector
gets to here.
This is represented as position dot add velocity,
velocity dot add acceleration.
We had to do all this extra work to sort of figure out
how we would manage all this data,
manipulate it because these were vectors.
Well, I want to do exactly the same thing with angles.
But in this funny way, we're going to make it much simpler.
We're backing up to our life before vectors
where we just use scalar quantities
because angle is a scalar value.
It's one number.
It's a single value.
Maybe it starts at 0.
Then I might have an angular velocity,
whatever that might be, and an angular acceleration,
whatever that might be.
And I don't know what makes sense to call these variables.
But I think angle, angular velocity,
angle A for angular acceleration,
that's going to work.
So this is what I want to first start with and add
to this sketch over here.
Back to the sketch, I'm going to add
a variable for angular velocity.
I'm going to add a variable for angular acceleration.
Then I'm going to, instead of having this hardcoded
to change by 0.05, I'm going to have the angle change
by angular velocity and the angular velocity change
by the angular acceleration.
And when I run the sketch, we can
see if those values are 0, the rectangle is not spinning.
It's not rotating.
There's no angular velocity or acceleration.
I could give it a little angular velocity, like 0.4.
And we can see, oh, it's spinning.
Actually, that's quite a high value.
0.2, it's spinning rather fast.
Again, in the clockwise direction,
if the angular velocity is negative 0.2,
it's going to then spin in the counterclockwise direction.
But it's spinning.
It's rotating at a constant angular velocity,
at a constant rate.
So let's look at what happens when I introduce
the idea of angular acceleration.
I'm going to use a very small number, 0.01,
and see what happens.
We can see it's quickly speeding up over time.
And now, it's cumulative.
That angular acceleration, 30 frames per second,
60 frames per second, is being added and added
and added to that angular velocity.
So it's spinning out of control.
The frame rate can't keep up.
It's actually creating some kind of unique, pretty interesting
visual artifacts.
But more likely, maybe to demonstrate this,
I'm going to give it an even smaller number,
so we can see it's speeding up over time.
The first thing that I might want to try to do with this
is just have that angular acceleration be variable.
Maybe I can map it to the mouse position
or some other parameter, so that it
feels like I can apply a force.
I'm pushing it to spin further.
I'm pulling it back to slow down,
go in the other direction, et cetera.
So let's, in Draw, I'm going to say angular acceleration.
I'm going to map just the mouse x position, which
goes between 0 and width, to some value between negative 0.01
I'm going to restart the sketch.
If I could get the mouse in the middle,
we could see here that the amount of acceleration
is very, very, very little.
And as I push it over to the right,
it's going to cause it to accelerate really fast.
But I can push it over to the left, which
is a force going in that's going to slow down and move backward.
So you can see how I'm able to interact with it.
And again, these numbers are still quite large.
But I can almost move back and forth
and get a little bit of a seesaw-like effect.
It might make sense to put some artificial constraints here.
So I might be able to say something
like constrain angle velocity between negative 0.5
Those are still pretty high numbers.
And let me actually make this a little bit lower,
just to emphasize that.
We can see that it's going to max out at a certain amount.
I might also suggest as an exercise,
could you do something where when you click the mouse,
you grab the rectangle.
You can spin it manually by moving the mouse around.
And then could you drag and release it
as if you're throwing it off in a given direction,
spinning a wheel, so to speak, that might slow down and stop.
That would be a great exercise to do.
I'll provide a solution for that in the description

I'd also like to take a look back
at the gravitational attraction example
from the end of chapter 2.
So here, there's an array of mover objects,

What happens if we add this concept of angular motion

So for example, if I were to add variables like this.angle

And let me just add all three of them as 0 right now.
I'm also going to need to add the translate function

Once again, that's explained in more detail in my P5.js

Now, even though I could add rotate by this.angle,

I could make them rectangles.

Now you can see there's a little line in each of them

I could try to add a ring around them as if they're planets

There's so many interesting possibilities.
But I'm just going to leave it something simple like that.
And then what would happen now if I were

Well, first of all, I need to add
the algorithm for angular motion in the update function.
So that should be.
So just like I have acceleration into velocity,

So let's now give them just all an arbitrary small angular
velocity.
And we can see they are all now rotating exactly the same speed

How about I try setting the angular acceleration

So maybe I'll just use the x value for right now.
I'm sitting here wondering why nothing has changed.
I realized I put this right after I set the acceleration

So this should really happen now at the very end of update.
Now I have a few things going on.
I have the algorithm to update velocity and position

to set the angle acceleration very arbitrarily

Let's run the sketch again.

Now, they're kind of spinning super out of control

Let's try something like just dividing it by 50.
And we can see there's a certain quality now
to how these objects rotate as they

Now, is it a realistic simulation?
Is there some actual thing that I'm modeling here

spin as it's moving, not even remotely close?
But I am experimenting visually here.
And if I were to have objects that

there's a lot of, I think, sort of visual possibilities
